awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Tunable Electrocatalysis at Buried Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will investigate electrochemical catalysis on metal catalysts that are fully- or partially-covered by ultra-thin layers of porous materials.  The coated catalysts will be evaluated for their effectiveness in promoting clean energy technologies related to fuel cells and reduction of carbon dioxide emissions.  The research will be coupled with teaching and outreach efforts emphasizing crowdsourcing tools and problem-based learning principles that actively engage students and citizen scientists in the generation and evaluation of innovative clean energy technologies. 

The project will focus on well-defined planar electrodes on which ultra-thin overlayers of silicon oxide and titanium oxide will be deposited by a room temperature ultraviolet (UV)- Ozone process that allows for nanometer-level control of the oxide thickness.  The thickness and surface chemistry of the oxide films will be tuned to control the selective transport of active species and/or modify the unique catalytic sites at the buried interface. The well-defined oxide-encapsulated electrocatalysts will be investigated for alcohol oxidation and carbon dioxide reduction using a suite of imaging and spectroscopy techniques that will enable i.) deconvolution of transport and kinetic effects, ii.) elucidation of the mechanisms by which ultrathin oxide overlayers influence reaction selectivity, and iii.) the development of design rules that can be applied across a wide range of materials and reactions. Experimental measurements will be closely coordinated with numerical modeling and density functional theory calculations performed by collaborators. A specific focus of this research is to compare the catalytic properties of buried oxide/metal interfaces to those at oxide/metal/electrolyte triple-phase boundary sites. Overall, the proposed research will lay the groundwork for the rational design of stable oxide-encapsulated electrocatalysts capable of highly efficient and selective generation and use of fuels.  Beyond the specific research, the project will launch an initiative entitled "Crowdsourcing for Energy Innovation" that will leverage emerging crowdsourcing principles and online tools to i.) accelerate training of today's students to become the inventors and evaluators of tomorrow's energy technology, ii.) increase participation in the Nation's innovation network, and iii.) increase student and public awareness of cutting-edge clean energy technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER award investigated a class of electrocatalyst materials for which the active catalyst component is encapsulated by a semi-permeable oxide overlayer having nanoscale thickness. Within this so-called oxide encapsulated electrocatalyst (OEC) architecture (see Figure), redox species diffuse between the electrolyte and active sites located at the buried interface between the active catalyst and oxide overlayer. By carrying out electrocatalytic reactions within the microenvironment at the buried interface, properly designed OECs offer an attractive approach towards improving the efficiency, selectivity, and durability of emerging clean technologies such as electrolyzers and fuel cells. However, there are significant technical challenges to studying buried interfaces and understanding the mechanisms by which overlayers impact the properties and performance of active sites located there.  To overcome these challenges and uncover the design rules that dictate the performance of OECs, this project focused on studying model thin film electrodes that allowed for excellent control over the chemical and physical characteristics of silicon (SiOx) and titanium oxide (TiOx) overlayers and comparison of experimental performance to 1D transport models. Several electrocatalytic reactions were investigated through this work, with most activities focused on the use of silicon oxide (SiOx) encapsulated platinum (Pt) thin film electrocatalysts for carbon monoxide (CO) and alcohol oxidation reactions.  Research carried out through this award resulted in several key outcomes representing significant advances in the scientific understanding of how OECs operate. Key technical outcomes and findings have included:

 (i) Demonstrating that the composition of oxide overlayers can be systematically tuned to control their selective transport properties and the chemical and physical properties of electrocatalytic buried interfaces. This outcome was achieved while maintaining sub 10 nm thickness of the overlayer, which is essential to sustain meaningful fluxes of electroactive species for real-world applications. These results demonstrate the high degree of tunability of oxide-encapsulated electrocatalysts using non-traditional “control knobs” that are not present in conventional electrocatalysts.

(ii) Uncovering trends in CO and alcohol oxidation activity of SiOx-encapsulated Pt thin film electrocatalysts having varied overlayer composition and structure were evaluated towards a series of eight different small molecules (Carbon monoxide, formic acid, methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, 1-butanol, 2-butanol). This study showed that carbon rich, low-density SiOx overlayers were capable of increasing alcohol oxidation current densities by 30-400% compared to bare Pt while promoting different reaction pathways for the methanol oxidation reaction.  Electroanalytical measurements, combined with product characterization, provided insights into the mechanistic origins of enhanced activity and varied reaction pathways for the encapsulated electrodes.   

(iii) Developing continuum-level 1-dimensional (1D) models that provide a theoretical framework for understanding and predicting differences in polarization curves and reaction selectivities for OECs and conventional electrocatalysts. This model allows the user to predict how transport properties (i.e. species permeabilities) of oxide overlayers affect activity (i.e partial current densities) and selectivity of oxide-encapsulated electrodes operating in the presence of two competing reactions.

(iv) Advanced the use of in situ spectroscopy techniques, namely liquid-phase ambient pressure X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (APXPS) and Raman spectroscopy, to study OECs in the electrochemical environment.  APXPS was used to probe the impact of the identity of supporting electrolyte anions on the electrostatic and chemical behavior of SiOx encapsulated Pt electrodes. In situ Raman measurements revealed the ability to see reactive intermediates at the OEC buried interface and showed that the presence of an overlayer can strongly impact the concentrations of near surface species compared to unencapsulated control samples.

This award has also resulted in several societal and educational broader impacts. First, dissemination of research findings through papers, book chapters, and presentations have led to a growing appreciation within the field of electrocatalysis for the ability to leverage transport phenomena through engineered nanoscopic coatings to tailor the activity, selectivity, and stability of electrocatalysts. The OEC approach has attracted interest from companies and led to the formation of a start-up company that was founded by a graduate student trained on this project.  In addition to training to PhD students, fourteen different students (6 masters students, 7 undergraduate students, and 1 post-baccalaureate student) have received training relating to electrocatalyst development through involvement on this project.  Efforts through this award also led to the development of educational resources for implementing crowdsourcing-related activities in coursework that promote critical and creating thinking about innovative clean technologies. These activities have been used extensively by the PI at Columbia, and have begun to spread to other classes at Columbia and other universities as well.   


Last Modified: 02/29/2024
Modified by: Daniel V Esposito

    Daniel Esposito
